WAR CABINET 65 (39).
CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street, S.W. 1, on Monday, October 30, 1939, at 11-30 a.m.
Present :
The Right Hon. Neville Chamberlain, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).
The Right Hon. Sir John Simon, K.C., M.P., Chancellor of the Exchequer.
Admiral of the Fleet the Right Hon. Lord Chatfield, Minister for Coordination of Defence.
The Right Hon. L. Hore-Belisha, M.P., Secretary of State for War.
The Right Hon. Sir Samuel Hoare, Bt., M.P., Lord Privy Seal.
The following were also present:
The Right Hon. Viscount Halifax, Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.
The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., First Lord of the Admiralty. The Right Hon. Sir Kingsley Wood,
M.P., Secretary of State for Air. The Right Hon. Lord Hankey, Minister without Portfolio.
The Right Hon. Sir John Anderson, M.P., Secretary of State for the Home Department and Minister of Home Security.

Air Chief Marshal Sir Cyril L. N. Newall, Chief of the Air Staff (Items 1-7).

The Secretary of Stale for War recalled that at the Meeting noted in the margin the War Cabinet had been informed of the concern evinced by the Egyptian Government as to the large number of Egyptian regular troops locked up on internal security duties in Egypt. The Egyptian Prime Minister had suggested the supply from Great Britain, gratis, of the equipment necessary for the organisation of an Egyptian Volunteer Force. He (the Secretary of State for War) had been invited to ascertain whether the equipment could be provided and to submit recommendations to the War Cabinet.
His Majesty's Ambassador in Cairo, the General Officer Commanding British Troops in Egypt, and General Macready had all been consulted and had advised against equipping the Volunteer Force until it had been trained. No further communication had been received from the Egyptian Government, and he therefore suggested that the scheme should be dropped.
The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs agreed.
The War Cabinet agreed that no further action should be taken on this question unless and until the Egyptian Government raised the matter again.

After dealing with religious questions and the role of the Church in the present crisis,

the Pope strongly condemned certain fundamental errors of the present time; for example, the laicising of society, the unlimited authority of the State over the individual, and the unilateral annulment of treaties, which destroyed that mutual confidence so essential to peaceful life between countries. At the conclusion of the encyclical His Holiness expressed deep sympathy with all oppressed beings, and especially the Poles.
The War Cabinet took note of the above statement.

10. The Chancellor of the Exchequer said that he had received a telegram from Lord Riverdale, who was now in Ottawa, in regard to the financial aspects of the plan for Imperial co-operation 4n Canada for the training of 50,000 pilots and air crew personnel a year for the Royal Air Force. The necessary personnel would be drawn from Canada, Australia, New Zealand and this country. The urgency of the matter lay in the fact that this question would be discussed by the Canadian Cabinet at a meeting to be held the following day (the 31st October, 1939), and it was essential that, before that meeting, Lord Riverdale should know whether we were prepared to accept our part of the financial burden proposed. The position might be summarised as follows :
The expenditure involved, which would need to be met partly in sterling and partly in Canadian dollars, covered a period of 3-| years, and was as follows :
(i) Expenditure to be met in sterling. Provision from this country of training machines and instructors . 50 millions.
(ii) Expenditure in Canadian dollars: $687 millions. (Capital expenditure, $260 millions; maintenance, $427 millions.)
The proposed allocation of the expenditure was as follows:
Millions.
United Kingdom ... ..." ... ... 50
Canada ............... $343^
Australia and New Zealand (in proportions
to be determined later)......... $343^
Neither Australia nor New Zealand was in a position to provide Canadian dollars, and we should therefore have to undertake to find the exchange (which amounted to the payment in gold of the sum in question). The transaction would be equivalent to our making loans to the two Dominions concerned, and repayment of any substantial part was not likely before the end of the war.
Continuing, the Chancellor of the Exchequer said that this scheme was of the utmost importance to the prosecution of the war. The provision of Canadian dollars on this scale would, however, involve
546
an equivalent reduction in the expenditure in dollars which would be possible for other urgent war purposes. If, therefore, this expenditure was to be incurred, it was necessary for the War Cabinet to give it an absolute priority.
The Secretary of State for Air said that the Canadian plan was designed to provide us with the number of pilots and air crew personnel required for the monthly programme of aircraft production already authorised. If for any other reason we were unable to achieve that programme, the expenditure in Canada would be correspondingly reduced. The expenditure would be spread over a considerable period, and the bulk would fall to be paid in the later years. Due credit should be given to the very heavy financial burden which under this scheme Canada would herself assume.
The War Cabinet agreed :
(a) to approve the proposal of the Chancellor of the Exchequer
that, in order to render possible the scheme for training 50,000 pilots and air crew personnel annually in Canada, His Majesty's Government should undertake to provide, in Canadian dollars, that portion of the cost of the scheme ($343^ millions) to be borne by Australia and New Zealand over a period of 3^ years, the sums so advanced to be repaid in sterling by the two Dominions concerned, it being recognised that in large part such repayment might have to take place after the war;
(b) that the provision of Canadian dollars for this transaction
should be accepted as having priority over other demands, it being understood that the provision of dollars on this scale would involve an equivalent reduction in the expenditure in dollars which would be available for other war purposes;
(c) that the Chancellor of the Exchequer and the Secretary of
State for Air should concert the terms of a telegram to be despatched to Lord Riverdale informing him of the Cabinet's decision.
Eire.
Control of communications between Eire, Northern Ireland and this country.
11. The First Lord of the Admiralty invited the attention of the War Cabinet to the position regarding telephone conversations between this country and Eire. There was as yet no arrangement by which the censorship authorities '' listened in " to such conversations. This was an inexplicable gap in our defences and we were running the risk of a leakage of vital information. It must not be forgotten that a German Minister was still in residence in Dublin.
The Secretary of State for War, in explaining the existing arrangements, said that there would be no difficulty in arranging for the censorship of telephone conversations with Eire. " Censorship " in these circumstances meant " listening in." This could be arranged without publicity and without the parties to the conversation being aware that they were overheard. On the other hand, the censoring of letters between this country and Eire would mean a considerable increase in the staff of the Censorship Department. The Eire Government had themselves already instituted a censorship over letters, telegrams, the press and broadcasting. Friendly relations existed between the Eire censorship authorities and our own.
The Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs pointed out that no effective check would be provided against the leakage of information unless telephone conversations with Northern Ireland were also controlled.
547

The War Cabinet agreed :
(a) To invite the Secretary of State for War, in consultation
with the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs, to arrange for censorship of telephone conversations between this country, Eire and Northern Ireland.
(b) To invite the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs to
consider whether the above decision should be communicated to Mr. Dulanty.
(c) In the event of any additional measure of control over
communications between this country and Eire being considered desirable, to invite the Secretary of State for War to consult with the Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs, with a view to framing a further recommendation to the War Cabinet.
Richmond Terrace, S.W.I, October 30, 1939.
